title: 112_s462
content: The "Elder Abuse Victims Act of 2011" may be cited as the official title of the Act. It includes definitions for key terms used within the Act. The "Elder Abuse Victims Act of 2011" defines key terms such as abuse, elder, exploitation, neglect, Director, Office, State, and task force. The "Elder Abuse Victims Act of 2011" defines key terms related to elder abuse, including abuse, exploitation, neglect, Director, Office, State, and task force. Additionally, it establishes the Office of Elder Justice. The Office of Elder Justice, established within the Department of Justice, is headed by a Director appointed by the President. The Director is responsible for creating, evaluating, and disseminating materials to assist in addressing elder abuse issues. The Office of Elder Justice, established within the Department of Justice, is responsible for preventing, understanding, and mitigating the impact of physical, sexual, and psychological abuse of elders, exploitation including financial abuse and scams, neglect, and assessing the trauma to victims. It also collects data to evaluate the efficacy of measures to prevent elder abuse and assess the number of victims in each State. The Office of Elder Justice evaluates the effectiveness of measures to prevent elder abuse and assesses the number of victims in each State. It also conducts evaluations on crime victim services, programs, and funding, publishes annual reports on the results, and evaluates training models for law enforcement officers and other professionals in victim services. The Office of Elder Justice evaluates measures to prevent elder abuse, assesses victims in each State, and conducts studies on laws and practices related to elder abuse, neglect, and exploitation. This includes investigating elder abuse cases, addressing legal issues, and interacting with victims and witnesses in various judicial proceedings. The Office of Elder Justice evaluates State laws and practices related to elder abuse, including enforcement effectiveness, definitions of abuse, neglect, and exploitation, and reporting mandates. The Office of Elder Justice evaluates State laws on elder abuse, including reporting requirements and enforcement effectiveness. It also reviews evidentiary and procedural issues related to elder abuse. The Office of Elder Justice evaluates State laws on elder abuse, neglect, and exploitation, including fiduciary laws, laws related to guardianship, conservatorship, power of attorney, prevention and reporting laws for employees of financial institutions, civil court proceedings, and laws related to fraud. The Office of Elder Justice evaluates State laws on elder abuse, neglect, and exploitation, including fraud and related activities in connection with mail, telemarketing, the Internet, or health care, programs addressing elder abuse, and other relevant State laws. Additionally, they carry out duties as determined necessary by the Attorney General to enhance understanding, prevention, detection, and response to elder abuse. SEC. 4. DATA COLLECTION. The Attorney General, in consultation with the Secretary of Health and Human Services, shall collect statistical data on elder abuse annually from law enforcement agencies and prosecutor offices, including the number of cases referred, filed in courts, and their outcomes. Common data points among different agencies will be identified. The Attorney General, in consultation with the Secretary of Health and Human Services, will collect national data on elder abuse from law enforcement agencies and prosecutor offices. The data will include the number of cases referred, filed in courts, and outcomes. Recommendations for collecting additional data on elder abuse will be developed. The Elder Victims Grant Program is established under Section 5. The Director may provide grants and technical assistance to 15 States to improve the response to elder abuse cases and enhance investigation and prosecution. States eligible for grants must have a crime victims compensation program meeting specific criteria and establish a task force. A State must establish a multidisciplinary task force on elder justice composed of professionals with knowledge of the criminal justice system and elder abuse issues. The task force should include representatives from law enforcement agencies, the crime victim compensation program, and judicial and legal officers. The multidisciplinary task force on elder justice includes professionals from various fields such as elder law advocates, health professionals, social services agencies, adult protective services, and family members of elder abuse victims. The task force is responsible for reviewing and evaluating responses to elder abuse cases in the State and making recommendations based on their findings. The multidisciplinary task force on elder justice, consisting of professionals from various fields, reviews and evaluates responses to elder abuse cases in the State. They make recommendations for modifying investigative, administrative, and judicial responses to reduce trauma to elder victims and ensure fairness to the accused. Additionally, they suggest experimental programs to improve prosecution rates. The State must submit a report evaluating the effectiveness of the grant program, listing all relevant laws on elder abuse, and providing any additional information requested by the Director within one year of receiving grant funds. The Director may require any other information. A State can designate a pre-2011 commission or task force as a task force. The Director can waive task force membership requirements. Grant funds can support State and local prosecutor offices and courts in elder abuse matters. The Director may require information for the grant program established under this section, including designating units to work on elder justice issues, hiring employees to coordinate cases and provide training, and evaluating the program within 1 year of final funds being awarded. The Director may require information for the grant program established under this section, including evaluating the program within 1 year of final funds being awarded and submitting a report with recommendations to Congress. The Social Security Act is amended to change the Elder Justice Coordinating Council. $20,000,000 is authorized for fiscal years 2012 through 2014 to carry out the Act.
